p: The American cranberry, Vaccinium macrocarpon, is a temperate perennial wetland plant native to northeastern North America. Native cranberries can still be found in moist low lying areas that naturally flood. Commercial cranberry bogs were first established in Massachusetts in the 1800s in peat-filled, impermeable kettle holes formed from glacial deposits. Many of the original kettle bogs are still in production today [ 49]. However, modern bogs (post 1986) are dug in upland habitat soil and made to replicate a wetland system.
